verses.verse: Then Job <WH347> answered <WH6030> and said <WH559>,
I know <WH3045> it is so of a truth <WH551>: but how should man <WH582> be just <WH6663> with God <WH410>?
If he will <WH2654> contend <WH7378> with him, he cannot answer <WH6030> him one <WH259> of a thousand <WH505>.
He is wise <WH2450> in heart <WH3824>, and mighty <WH533> in strength <WH3581>: who hath hardened <WH7185> himself against him, and hath prospered <WH7999>?
Which removeth <WH6275> the mountains <WH2022>, and they know <WH3045> not: which overturneth <WH2015> them in his anger <WH639>.
Which shaketh <WH7264> the earth <WH776> out of her place <WH4725>, and the pillars <WH5982> thereof tremble <WH6426>.
Which commandeth <WH559> the sun <WH2775>, and it riseth <WH2224> not; and sealeth up <WH2856> the stars <WH3556>.
Which alone spreadeth out <WH5186> the heavens <WH8064>, and treadeth <WH1869> upon the waves <WH1116> of the sea <WH3220>.
Which maketh <WH6213> Arcturus <WH5906>, Orion <WH3685>, and Pleiades <WH3598>, and the chambers <WH2315> of the south <WH8486>.
Which doeth <WH6213> great things <WH1419> past <WH369> finding out <WH2714>; yea, and wonders <WH6381> without number <WH4557>.
Lo, he goeth <WH5674> by me, and I see <WH7200> him not: he passeth on <WH2498> also, but I perceive <WH995> him not.
Behold, he taketh away <WH2862>, who can hinder <WH7725> him? who will say <WH559> unto him, What doest <WH6213> thou?
If God <WH433> will not withdraw <WH7725> his anger <WH639>, the proud <WH7293> helpers <WH5826> do stoop <WH7817> under him.
How much less shall I answer <WH6030> him, and choose out <WH977> my words <WH1697> to reason with him?
Whom, though I were righteous <WH6663>, yet would I not answer <WH6030>, but I would make supplication <WH2603> to my judge <WH8199>.
If I had called <WH7121>, and he had answered <WH6030> me; yet would I not believe <WH539> that he had hearkened <WH238> unto my voice <WH6963>.
For he breaketh <WH7779> me with a tempest <WH8183>, and multiplieth <WH7235> my wounds <WH6482> without cause <WH2600>.
He will not suffer <WH5414> me to take <WH7725> my breath <WH7307>, but filleth <WH7646> me with bitterness <WH4472>.
If I speak of strength <WH3581>, lo, he is strong <WH533>: and if of judgment <WH4941>, who shall set <WH3259> me a time to plead?
If I justify <WH6663> myself, mine own mouth <WH6310> shall condemn <WH7561> me: if I say, I am perfect <WH8535>, it shall also prove me perverse <WH6140>.
Though I were perfect <WH8535>, yet would I not know <WH3045> my soul <WH5315>: I would despise <WH3988> my life <WH2416>.
This is one <WH259> thing, therefore I said <WH559> it, He destroyeth <WH3615> the perfect <WH8535> and the wicked <WH7563>.
If the scourge <WH7752> slay <WH4191> suddenly <WH6597>, he will laugh <WH3932> at the trial <WH4531> of the innocent <WH5355>.
The earth <WH776> is given <WH5414> into the hand <WH3027> of the wicked <WH7563>: he covereth <WH3680> the faces <WH6440> of the judges <WH8199> thereof; if not, where <WH645>, and who is he?
Now my days <WH3117> are swifter <WH7043> than a post <WH7323>: they flee away <WH1272>, they see <WH7200> no good <WH2896>.
They are passed away <WH2498> as <WH5973> the swift <WH16> ships <WH591>: as the eagle <WH5404> that hasteth <WH2907> to the prey <WH400>.
If I say <WH559>, I will forget <WH7911> my complaint <WH7879>, I will leave off <WH5800> my heaviness <WH6440>, and comfort <WH1082> myself:
I am afraid <WH3025> of all my sorrows <WH6094>, I know <WH3045> that thou wilt not hold me innocent <WH5352>.
If I be wicked <WH7561>, why then labour <WH3021> I in vain <WH1892>?
If I wash <WH7364> myself with <WH7950> snow water <WH4325> <WH1119>, and make my hands <WH3709> never <WH1252> <WH1253> so clean <WH2141>;
Yet <WH227> shalt thou plunge <WH2881> me in the ditch <WH7845>, and mine own clothes <WH8008> shall abhor <WH8581> me.
For he is not a man <WH376>, as I am, that I should answer <WH6030> him, and we should come <WH935> together <WH3162> in judgment <WH4941>.
Neither is <WH3426> there any daysman <WH3198> betwixt us, that might lay <WH7896> his hand <WH3027> upon us both <WH8147>.
Let him take <WH5493> his rod <WH7626> away <WH5493> from me, and let not his fear <WH367> terrify <WH1204> me:
Then would I speak <WH1696>, and not fear <WH3372> him; but it is not so with me.
